titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Max Fleischman Letter to A. Fleischman, 1930 May 14 RL.11626
titlestmt.author: Alice Poffinberger

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: Max Fleischman letter to A. Fleischman,
did.abstract: Max Fleischman was possibly serving as a salesman in Texas in 1930. His family lived in Plainfield, New Jersey. Collection comprises an autograph letter signed (7 pages) by Max Fleischman, written to his family in Plainfield, New Jersey, on Liberty Hotel stationary from Cleburne, Texas, dated 1930 May 14. Topics in the letter include the lynching and burning of the courthouse in Sherman, Texas, on May 9. Other topics include damage from a tornado that passed through Frost, Texas, on May 6, his plans to build a miniature golf course, as well as family matters and questions. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Max Fleischman was possibly serving as a salesman in Texas in 1930. His family lived in Plainfield, New Jersey.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Max Fleischman Letter to A. Fleischman was received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a purchase in 2018.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Accessions described in this collection guide: 2018-0069

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection comprises an autograph letter signed (7 pages) by Max Fleischman, written to his family in Plainfield, New Jersey, on Liberty Hotel stationary from Cleburne, Texas, dated 1930 May 14. Topics in the letter include the lynching and burning of the courthouse in Sherman, Texas, on May 9: "It's a nice little town, and one would never think that people like them would lynch anybody. But some of these Texans still have pioneer fighting blood in them." Other topics include damage from a tornado that passed through Frost, Texas, on May 6, his plans to build a miniature golf course, as well as family matters and questions. Includes enclosure. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.
